DOC.HEAD: Aquino Calls For Unity, Filipinos Light Candles For Peace
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino called on Filipinos in a Christmas message to join together to help the country recover from the most recent coup attempt. Thousands of people lighted candles in a plea for peace. ``The candles we will be lighting as one symbolize the longing of the ordinary citizen for peace and tranquility and his repudiation of violence as an instrument of power,'' The Manila Chronicle said in a front-page editorial. Mrs. Aquino said the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt tarnished the country's reputation and stalled efforts to improve the economy still suffering from 20 years of rule under former President Ferdinand Marcos. ``What we need to do today is to join hands so that we can regain the momentum that we lost, so that we can heal the wounds that were inflicted upon us,'' Mrs. Aquino said. Marcos was ousted in a February 1986 military-civilian uprising that propelled Mrs. Aquino to power. Marcos died in September in exile in Hawaii. In another statement Monday, the Central Committee of the banned Communist Party of the Philippines blamed the December coup attempt on Mrs. Aquino's failure to solve the country's economic, social and political problems. The party claimed the country was drifting toward a new era of repression because of the growing influence of the military faction that has quelled six coup attempts during the Aquino administration. The December coup try was the worst, leaving at least 113 people dead. ``The recent upsurge of popular unrest owing to the worsening political and economic crisis, the military rebellion in December, and the shameless manner in which the Aquino regime asked for U.S. succor to quell the rebellion have dramatically ... exposed its ineptitude to rule,'' the party said in a statement distributed to news organizations. The statement was issued to mark the 21st anniversary of the Communist Party of the Philippines, founded Dec. 26, 1968. Thousands of candles flickered in front of homes, businesses and military camps across the politically troubled land. The nationwide candle-lighting ceremony was organized by entertainer Danny Javier in a bid to forge national unity in the wake of the coup and amid insurgencies by Marxist and Moslem rebels. People were urged to place one candle in front of their home for each member of the household as a gesture of peace and national reconciliation. Hundreds of thousands of Filipinos also crowded churches in Asia's only predominately Christian country to pray for peace. In his Christmas message, Roman Catholic Cardinal Jaime L. Sin said violence had drowned out the ``song of peace and good will that was sung by the heavenly choir over Bethlehem on that first Christmas.''
